subject: Photography
title: How Autofocus Works
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on How Autofocus Works.

hook.text: You press the shutter halfway and the image snaps into focus. Behind that click, a tiny computer works furiously.

buildup.text: Autofocus systems move lens elements until the subject appears sharp on the sensor.

discovery.text: Phase detection splits incoming light into pairs and measures their alignment. When aligned, the subject is sharp.

twist.text: Contrast detection analyzes sharpness by looking for maximum edge contrast. It's accurate but hunts back and forth.

climax.text: Modern cameras combine both methods â€” fast phase detection refined by precise contrast analysis.

punchline.text: Autofocus is a tiny robot adjusting glass at incredible speed.

quiz.question: How does phase-detection autofocus determine focus?
options: It splits light into pairs and checks their alignment
It measures the color of the subject
It uses sound waves like sonar
